title: Significance of coil orientation for motor evoked potentials from nasalis muscle elicited by transcranial magnetic stimulation.
journal: Clinical neurophysiology : official journal of the International Federation of Clinical Neurophysiology
abstract: In transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) of the motor cortex, the optimal orientation of the coil on the scalp is dependent on the muscle under investigation, but not yet known for facial muscles.

title: Modulation of H-reflex excitability by tetanic stimulation.
journal: Clinical neurophysiology : official journal of the International Federation of Clinical Neurophysiology
abstract: Using a figure-of-eight coil, we compared TMS induced motor evoked potentials (MEPs) from eight different coil orientations when recording from ipsi- and contralateral nasalis muscle.

title: Comparison of descending volleys evoked by transcranial and epidural motor cortex stimulation in a conscious patient with bulbar pain.
journal: Clinical neurophysiology : official journal of the International Federation of Clinical Neurophysiology
abstract: The MEPs from nasalis muscle revealed three components: The major ipsi- and contra-lateral middle latency responses of approximately 10 ms onset latency proved entirely dependent on voluntary pre-innervation. They were most easily obtained from a coil orientation with posterior inducing current direction, and in this respect resembled the intrinsic hand rather than the masseter muscles. Early short duration responses of around 6 ms onset latency were best elicited with an antero-lateral current direction and not pre-innervation dependent, and therefore most probably due to stimulation of the nerve roots. Late responses (>18 ms) could inconsistently be elicited with posterior coil orientations in pre-innervated condition.

title: Impact of coil position and electrophysiological monitoring on determination of motor thresholds to transcranial magnetic stimulation.
journal: Clinical neurophysiology : official journal of the International Federation of Clinical Neurophysiology
abstract: By using the appropriate coil orientation and both conditions relaxed and pre-innervated, cortically evoked MEP responses from nasalis muscle can reliably be separated from peripheral and reflex components and also from cross talk of masseter muscle activation.

title: The effects of repetitive proprioceptive stimulation on corticomotor representation in intact and hemiplegic individuals.
journal: Clinical neurophysiology : official journal of the International Federation of Clinical Neurophysiology
abstract: This study investigated a strategy to elicit reversible facilitation of the soleus monosynaptic H-reflex in humans using a modified tetanic stimulation technique.

title: Inhibitory interactions between pairs of subthreshold conditioning stimuli in the human motor cortex.
journal: Clinical neurophysiology : official journal of the International Federation of Clinical Neurophysiology
abstract: Interventional tetanic stimulation (ITS) was applied to the tibial nerve in the popliteal fossa, and soleus H-reflexes were recorded before and after stimulation in 15 healthy volunteers.

title: Motor cortex excitability in transient global amnesia.
abstract: ITS resulted in significantly increased soleus H-reflex amplitudes that outlasted the stimulation period by approximately 16 min. The effect of ITS on soleus motor evoked potentials to transcranial magnetic stimulation and on somatosensory evoked potentials to tibial nerve stimulation was also investigated; no significant changes were found.

title: [Transcranial magnetic stimulation. Applications in cognitive neuroscience].
abstract: ITS produced a reversible increase in H-reflexes in the absence of changes in motor evoked potential or somatosensory evoked potential that outlasted the intervention period for up to 16 min.

title: Modulation of corticospinal excitability and intracortical inhibition during motor imagery is task-dependent.
journal: Experimental brain research. Experimentelle Hirnforschung. Expérimentation cérébrale
abstract: This technique may be used in future studies to investigate whether the induced increased H-reflex excitability influences locomotion.

title: Cortical excitability in neuroleptic-naive first-episode schizophrenic patients.
abstract: To compare the pattern of activation of motor cortex produced by transcranial magnetic stimulation and epidural electrical stimulation.
